title: Cinema Vocabulary
description: Lights, camera, action! How well do you know filmmaking terminology?

questions.question: In filmmaking, what is a 'dolly shot'?
options: A close-up of a character's face
A shot featuring a doll or puppet
A shot where the camera moves on a wheeled platform
A shot taken from above
questions.explanation: A dolly shot involves the camera mounted on a wheeled platform (dolly) that rolls along tracks or a smooth surface, creating fluid forward, backward, or lateral movement.

questions.question: What does 'mise-en-scène' mean in cinema?
options: A scene filmed on location
A musical scene in a film
The final edited version of a film
The arrangement of everything that appears in the frame
questions.explanation: Mise-en-scène (French for 'placing on stage') refers to everything visible in the frame: set design, lighting, costumes, props, and the arrangement of actors.

questions.question: In film, what is a 'MacGuffin'?
options: A type of camera lens
A comedic character type
A plot device that motivates characters but has little importance itself
A special effects technique
questions.explanation: A MacGuffin is a plot device, often an object or goal, that drives the characters' actions but is ultimately unimportant to the story. Alfred Hitchcock popularized the term.

questions.question: What is a 'gaffer' in film production?
options: The chief electrician responsible for lighting
The person who manages extras
The person who operates the boom microphone
The assistant director
questions.explanation: The gaffer is the chief electrician on a film set, responsible for the execution of the lighting plan in collaboration with the director of photography.

questions.question: In cinema, what does 'montage' refer to?
options: A sequence of short shots edited together to condense time or information
The opening credits
A single long take without cuts
A mountain scene in a film
questions.explanation: A montage is a filmmaking technique where a series of short shots are edited together to condense time, convey information, or create a specific emotional effect.

questions.question: What is a 'key grip' on a film set?
options: The lead actor's personal assistant
The person who holds the clapperboard
The head of the grip department responsible for camera support and rigging
The person who locks the set doors
questions.explanation: The key grip is the head of the grip department, overseeing all rigging, camera support equipment, dollies, cranes, and anything that shapes or blocks light on set.

questions.question: In film, what is a 'tracking shot'?
options: A shot that follows animal tracks
A time-lapse recording
A shot used to track continuity errors
A shot where the camera moves alongside or follows a subject
questions.explanation: A tracking shot is any shot where the camera physically moves through space to follow, lead, or move alongside a subject, creating dynamic and immersive visuals.

questions.question: What does 'foley' refer to in filmmaking?
options: A special camera filter
A film shot in slow motion
The reproduction of everyday sound effects added in post-production
A type of film festival
questions.explanation: Foley is the art of creating and recording everyday sound effects (footsteps, clothing rustles, door creaks) in post-production to enhance the audio realism of a film.

questions.question: In cinema, what is a 'jump cut'?
options: Editing out action sequences
A cut to a scene with jumping
An abrupt transition between two shots that breaks continuity
A cut from one camera angle to a drastically different one
questions.explanation: A jump cut is an abrupt edit between two sequential shots of the same subject from slightly different positions, creating a jarring effect that breaks spatial or temporal continuity.

questions.question: What is 'aspect ratio' in cinema?
options: The proportional relationship between the width and height of the image
The ratio of actors to crew members
The ratio of dialogue to action in a film
The percentage of the budget spent on special effects
questions.explanation: Aspect ratio describes the proportional relationship between the width and height of a film's image, such as 16:9 (widescreen) or 4:3 (standard).

questions.question: In filmmaking, what is 'ADR'?
options: Advanced Digital Recording
Assistant Director's Report
Artistic Design Review
Automated Dialogue Replacement
questions.explanation: ADR (Automated Dialogue Replacement, also called 'looping') is the process of re-recording dialogue in a studio after filming, to replace unclear or unusable original audio.

questions.question: What is a 'storyboard' in filmmaking?
options: A bulletin board listing the cast
A sequence of drawn panels illustrating planned shots and scenes
The schedule for filming
A board game based on a movie
questions.explanation: A storyboard is a series of illustrated panels that pre-visualize the sequence of shots in a film, helping directors plan camera angles, framing, and scene progression.

questions.question: In cinema, what does 'pan' mean?
options: A panoramic landscape shot
A negative review of the film
A horizontal rotation of the camera from a fixed position
A cooking scene
questions.explanation: A pan is a camera movement where the camera rotates horizontally (left or right) on its axis from a stationary position, used to follow action or reveal a scene.

questions.question: What is a 'cliffhanger' in cinema?
options: A scene filmed on a cliff
A dramatic camera angle from above
A stunt involving hanging from a height
An unresolved ending that leaves the audience in suspense
questions.explanation: A cliffhanger is a narrative device where a story ends at a moment of high suspense or unresolved conflict, compelling the audience to want to see the resolution.

questions.question: In filmmaking, what is a 'best boy'?
options: The lead animal trainer
The youngest crew member
The chief assistant to either the gaffer or the key grip
The director's favorite actor
questions.explanation: The best boy is the chief assistant to either the gaffer (best boy electric) or the key grip (best boy grip), helping manage the electrical or grip department crew and equipment.
